I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will provide selected developing 
member countries (DMCs) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) with policy advice, capacity 
building, and knowledge resources to create the legal and policy environment for private sector 
investment and public–private partnership (PPP) projects. The TA will build on and supplement 
other ADB initiatives to foster PPP-enabling reforms and promote private sector participation,1 
and deliver targeted assistance, as identified in consultation with ADB departments and offices 
as well as government and court authorities. 
 
2.  The TA is aligned with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and the goal of expanding private sector 
operations. This includes scaling up assistance for PPPs to support ADB’s seven operational 
priorities and also underpins the planning directions for 2021—building the capacity of DMCs for 
implementing PPPs, and strengthening the enabling environment for PPPs in coordination with 
the regional departments, the Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD), and the PPP 
Thematic Group Secretariat.2 The TA will also support (i) the Operational Plan for Private Sector 
Operations: 2019–2024; and (ii) the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) 9 
(industry, innovation, and infrastructure); 16 (peace, justice, and strong institutions); and 17 
(partnerships for the goals).3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  The private sector has contributed significantly to economic growth in the Asia and Pacific 
region,  generating  jobs,  tax  revenues,  and  many  innovations  that  improve  efficiency  and 
productivity. Private sector resources will also be needed to tackle a regional infrastructure gap 
of about $1.7 trillion per year.4 However, to increase private sector investment and bridge that 
gap, DMCs first need to create or strengthen certain critical building blocks. 
 
4.  Effective policy, legislative, and regulatory framework. DMCs must develop effective 
policies, legislation, and regulations that are transparent and able to address the many issues 
inherent in any complex infrastructure project—e.g., foreign investments, taxation, contractual 
rights of parties and enforceability of contracts, land rights, and resource allocations—all of which 
affect the feasibility and bankability of such a project. The legal and regulatory regime is critical 
for the success of a PPP because it ensures the stability of the procurement process and

contractual management, and is an essential part of due diligence by investors and lenders.5 
Even where laws have been enacted, DMCs need assistance with the formulation of detailed 
regulations and standard operating procedures.6 Policy and regulatory constraints also create 
bankability issues and limit the ability to source capital for infrastructure projects. In response to 
these issues, ADB partnered with private sector entities to set up a debt financing platform to 
boost the commercial development of sustainable infrastructure projects in Asia. ADB, as a 
strategic partner to the private sector equity partners, will provide TA to support both upstream 
legal reform work as well as downstream project-specific activities to turn marginally bankable 
projects into bankable ones.7 
 
5.  The implications of insolvency and other commercial laws in relation to infrastructure 
projects are extensive, especially in limited recourse finance projects and PPP projects.8 Having 
a robust PPP law backed by a commercial legal framework that provides for protection of lender 
rights and fair treatment by the government throughout the project life increases the bankability 
of PPP initiatives.9 A review of insolvency laws in Armenia and Viet Nam, for instance, reveals a 
need to modernize these and create a more predictable business environment that will boost 
lender confidence and expand credit availability.10 
 
6.  Strong governance and institutional framework. DMCs also need strong institutional 
and governance frameworks with well-developed entities and experienced public officials to 
manage, identify, and mitigate risks associated with complex infrastructure projects.11 Certain 
DMCs face acute capacity constraints and need comprehensive assistance to improve PPP 
development and public service delivery.12 Indonesia, for example, is experiencing project delays 
because government contracting agencies have insufficient capacity to properly prepare and 
procure projects  on par with international standards, but also because government stakeholders 
lack coordination and clear lines of responsibility.13

7.  Access to knowledge products and quality model documentation. DMCs also need 
(i)  information  regarding  best  practices,  innovative  and  suitable  structures,  models  for  the 
implementation of such projects, and lessons from developed and developing jurisdictions;14 and 
(ii) quality precedent documentation from successful project financings and PPP projects that can 
be  replicated. 15  Insufficient  guidelines  and  model  documents  for  various  sectors  have 
discouraged private sector investments in DMCs such as Pakistan.16 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: private sector investment and operations 
(including PPPs) in selected DMCs to support ADB’s seven operational priorities (Strategy 2030); 
and SDGs 9, 16, and 17 increased.17 The TA will have the following outcome: legal, regulatory, 
and  policy  frameworks  for  selected  DMCs;  and  capacity  development  for  private  sector 
development and the financing of infrastructure projects, including those implemented as PPPs, 
improved.18 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  Output 1: Legal, regulatory, and policy framework for private sector investment 
improved. The TA will help reform the legal, regulatory, and/or policy frameworks to ensure an 
enabling environment for the private sector. It will support the drafting and reviewing of policy 
documents,  laws,  and/or  regulations  (with  an  initial  focus  on  the  formulation  or  reform  of 
insolvency laws) to promote private sector development and investment. 
 
10.  Output 2: Model template documentation for infrastructure projects developed. The 
TA will assist key public sector institutions in drafting template documentation for the development 
and  financing  of  infrastructure  projects.  Model  legal  documents  will  be  based  on  the 
documentation for projects that have achieved financial close in relevant DMCs and can serve as 
precedents, such as implementation, supply, and offtake agreements; financing documents and 
direct agreements; government guarantees and support agreements; regulatory instruments such 
as licenses; and concession agreements and tendering documents for PPP projects. 
 
11.  Output 3: Capacity of key public sector agencies and government stakeholders 
strengthened. The TA will improve the skills and knowledge of public sector agencies and 
government stakeholders in selected DMCs to produce an enabling environment for the private 
sector and to implement and manage infrastructure projects. The TA will provide training, either 
to specific DMCs or regional trainings and conferences, on (i) policy, law, and regulatory reform; 
(ii) infrastructure project development and financing; and/or (iii) the operationalization of recently 
enacted or reformed legal, regulatory, and contractual frameworks.  
 
14 ADB. 2019. Public–Private Partnership Monitor, Second Edition. Manila. In one DMC, the lack of knowledge about 
PPPs and the changing legal and institutional framework delayed the progress of PPPs in the energy sector. In 
another DMC, the lack of well-structured projects limited the development of PPPs despite investor appetite to finance 
PPP projects. Those DMCs that have emerging PPP markets and recently established PPP legislation need access 
to knowledge products to assist the governments in identifying the risks for a given PPP project and allocating those 
risks between the private sector and public sector or where such risks are shared between the parties. 
15 ADB. 2012. PPP Operational Plan. Manila. 
16 ADB. 2021. Public–Private Partnership Monitor: Pakistan. Manila. 
17 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. Manila 
(Section VII: Expanding Private Sector Operations). 
18 A DMC may request assistance under one or more outputs. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
 
12.  Output 4: Knowledge resources on private sector and PPP projects developed. The 
TA will support the preparation and dissemination of reports and comparative studies to identify 
(i) market-tested approaches and international best practices in developed and developing 
markets; (ii) constraints inhibiting, or readiness factors necessary for, the promotion of private 
sector investment and the PPP modality; and (iii) lessons and trends emerging in DMCs with 
respect to commercial law reform, infrastructure project development, financing, policy, legislative, 
and regulatory reform, and procurement practices. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,539,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund ($106,000 from TASF 6; $1,000,000 from TASF 7; and 
$433,000 from TASF-other sources). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB, through the Office of the General Counsel’s Law and Policy Reform Program, will 
be the executing agency and will administer the TA. The TA will be implemented from January 
2022 to December 2025. Based on consultations with ADB departments and offices as well as 
government and court authorities, the TA may initially target (i) Armenia,19 Bhutan,20 Indonesia,21 
and Viet Nam22 to reform their respective insolvency laws; (ii) Mongolia to create an enabling 
environment for PPPs;23 (iii) Indonesia and Viet Nam under Project Regeneration (i.e., the debt 
financing platform set up by ADB and its private sector partners) (para. 4 and footnote 7) to 
provide  supplementary  resources  and  legal  support  on  upstream  legislative  activities  for 
sustainable infrastructure projects; and (iv) Kazakhstan and the Kyrgyz Republic to assist a cross-
border road project by supporting preliminary screening and assessment of the legal frameworks 
of the two jurisdictions.24 In addition, ADB’s Office of the General Counsel will continue to consult

Partnership Projects through Support for Law and Policy Development and Transaction Advisory Services. Manila 
(TA 8998-REG). The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development is a potential development partner.

Thematic Group, and other sector and thematic groups to determine DMCs' participation and to

collaborate with development partners—such as the United Nations Commission on International

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,539,000 on a grant basis for 
Law and Policy Development for Private Sector and Public–Private Partnership Projects, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
25 The selection criteria for the TA are that (i) a regional department or PSOD is involved in the financing, or OPPP is 
involved in an advisory mandate for a project; (ii) support for an upstream enabling environment or capacity building 
was identified in the CPS or the indicative country pipeline and monitoring; (iii) ADB has previously provided support 
to a DMC, and the DMC seeks follow-on or additional support under this TA; or (iv) ADB has received other requests 
from a DMC for one or more of the outputs under this TA. The country teams concerned have agreed to include this 
TA in the indicative country pipeline and monitoring reports for Armenia, Bhutan, Indonesia, Mongolia, Papua New 
Guinea, and Viet Nam. For any proposed support to Pacific DMCs, the TA team will ensure coordination with ADB’s 
Private Sector Development Initiative. The actual participation of DMCs identified through initial consultations will be 
subject to government consultations and the availability of TA resources. A no-objection letter will be obtained from 
each participating DMC before financing or carrying out any TA activities.

consultation with the Office of Public–Private Partnership, the Private Sector Operations Department, 
regional departments, and sector and thematic groups (the selection of DMCs will be demand-driven and 
will occur throughout the implementation period) (January 2022–December 2024).

agreements in consultation with the Office of Public–Private Partnership, the Private Sector Operations 
Department, regional departments, and sector and thematic groups (the identification of DMCs in need of 
model documents will be demand-driven and will occur throughout the implementation period) 
(January 2022–December 2024).
